awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Framework: Machine Learning Materials Innovation Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Machine learning is rapidly changing our society, with computers recently gaining skills in many new tasks. These tasks range from understanding language to driving cars. Materials science and engineering is also being transformed. Many tasks are becoming increasingly accessible to machine learning algorithms. These range from predicting new data to analyzing images. Many basic machine learning algorithms are readily available. However the overall workflow involved in the application of machine learning for materials problems is still largely executed by hand. Getting results out is still done by traditional methods like publishing articles. There is an enormous opportunity to accelerate the growth and impact of machine learning in materials research. This requires improved cyberinfrastructure. This project will develop an approach to accelerate the entire machine learning workflow. Its output will include tools to easily develop datasets, manage model development, and output models. These will be reusable and reproducible for future use. This project will enable materials scientists and engineers to rapidly develop and deploy machine learning models. More importantly, the entire materials community will be able to quickly access these models. It will transform how we discover and develop advanced materials.

The project will have three major technical components: (i) A MAterials Simulation Toolkit for Machine Learning (MAST-ML) with workflow tools that will enable local or cloud-based multistep, automated execution of complex machine learning data analysis and model training, codified best practices, increased access to machine learning methods for non-experts, and accelerated model development; (ii) The Foundry Materials Informatics Environment that will provide flexible, integrated, cloud-based management of machine learning materials science and engineering projects, from organizing data to developing models to disseminating results that are machine and human accessible and reproducible in ways that support a networked materials innovation ecosystem, (iii) Representative science applications of machine learning materials science and engineering projects that will support infrastructure development and promotion, as well as demonstrate best practices on state-of-the-art materials science and engineering problems. In addition to its impact on materials science and engineering, this project will develop students and young researchers with the interdisciplinary skills of machine learning and materials science and engineering, and promote these new ideas to the broader materials community. This award is jointly supported by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure, and the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Materials and chemistry plays a critical role in society, enabling advances in microelectronics, communications, medical treatments and devices, energy generation, storage, and transmission, and supporting national defense. Yet, the pace of discovery and application of these new materials remains too slow. Researchers face a significant challenge: finding, sharing, and using high-quality scientific data to develop new materials and technologies. In this project, the University of Chicago, in collaboration with partners at the University of Wisconsin developed Foundry-ML – an innovative software platform that makes it easier for scientists to share and access the highest quality research data and even machine learning models in seconds with just a few lines of code rather than with weeks or months of effort prior to Foundry-ML.

What is Foundry-ML? Foundry-ML is user-friendly software that helps researchers discover, access, and share scientific datasets, particularly those used in machine learning for materials science and chemistry applications. We also made significant progress towards enabling publication, discovery, and reuse of machine learning models.

Some key achievements of the project include:

  1. Simplified Data Access: Researchers can now access high-quality, curated scientific datasets with just a few lines of computer code (Fig. 1). This dramatically reduces the time and effort needed to begin new research projects, and allows researchers to more easily build upon the prior work of others. As part of this project, we collected and made available 61 diverse materials and chemistry datasets, comprising millions of data points, with applications ranging from polymer and drug discovery to microscopy benchmark datasets and semiconductor property prediction. These datasets are available via programmatic interfaces, or through a simple web user interface (Fig. 2). With our sustainable software, other researchers will be able to publish more of these datasets in the future.

  2. Educational Impact: The platform has been successfully integrated into university curricula, helping train the next generation of scientists. Leading institutions like Northwestern University have incorporated Foundry-ML into their teaching programs. The team delivered many presentations at workshops and online to help train researchers and students not only how to use Foundry-ML, but also to adopt best practices around data sharing in materials science and chemistry. These efforts reached hundreds of students.

  3. Industry Adoption: Major companies like 3M have chosen to use Foundry-ML to share their research data, demonstrating the platform's value in bridging academic and industrial research.

  4. Real Research Use: With our Wisconsin collaborators (Dane Morgan, Ryan Jacobs, Paul Voyles, et al), we showed the promise of Foundry-ML and shared all of the datasets associated with a paper where models were developed for 33 materials properties spanning an array of data sources (computational and experimental) and property types (electrical, mechanical, thermodynamic, etc). Further, all of the models were published in a way that allows users to fully connect datasets with models and to reproduce the work fully.

Why is this work important: Before Foundry-ML, researchers often had to spend weeks or months tracking down, collecting, cleaning, and formatting data for their studies. This would often require reaching out to a group by email and asking for data from a specific paper. Now, they can access ready-to-use datasets, purpose built for machine learning in seconds. Further, other researchers can share their cleaned datasets with Foundry-ML in a way that makes it trivial for others to reuse them.

Future Work: Looking to the future, the team is working to expand Foundry-ML's capabilities through open source development. Plans include connecting datasets with machine learning models and extending the platform's use beyond materials science and chemistry to other scientific fields. This expansion will help create a more connected and efficient scientific research ecosystem.

The success of Foundry-ML demonstrates how modern software tools can lower barriers in scientific research. By making data more accessible and easier to use, the project is helping accelerate the pace of scientific discovery and innovation, ultimately benefiting society through faster development of new materials and technologies.

All code, and data generated in this project have been made available via open source licenses, which will allow the community and open source contributors to maintain, and continue building upon the datasets and software created here. The team has built a community around open source data and software, and will use this to continue support for Foundry-ML to ensure these capabilities remain available to researchers.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Benjamin Blaiszik

Images (1 of )
  • Foundry Website UI for browsing Datasets. This figure shows a web user interface for browsing available datasets with summary information about the datasets.
    B. Blaiszik
    Public Domain
    Benjamin Blaiszik
    Foundry datasets web view
  • A Foundry-ML use case for zeolite design. (a) A user instantiates the Foundry-ML Python client and loads the descriptive metadata using the DOI. (b) Descriptive metadata includes information about the keys included in the datasets, associated units, a short description and more.
    B. Blaiszik
    Public Domain
    Benjamin Blaiszik
    Foundry-ML for Zeolite design
